assignments.utilization_method: Stand the (preferably empty) soda can upright. Touch the selfie-stick tip to the center of the can’s top. The thin aluminum panel flexes imperceptibly at first and then firms up, giving a graded resistance and a faint elastic rebound comparable to pushing soft bristles into primed canvas.

Grip the battery lengthwise in a tripod grip. Its 1.4 cm diameter metal cylinder and low mass are very close to a real marker’s feel, allowing highly accurate pen-like strokes and fingertip rotations to change orientation.

physical_object.name: yellow and orange Japanese snack bag

assignments.utilization_method: Hold the sealed corner of the bag like a tube’s neck. With the other hand, apply rolling pressure from the opposite end toward the ‘nozzle’ corner; the air-filled foil bag compresses and wrinkles under your fingers, providing a convincingly soft, deformable response closely matching the feel of squeezing paint out of a tube.

Lay a straight section of the cable flat on the desk and press it lightly so it doesn’t shift. Draw the battery tip along the cable’s smooth vinyl jacket; the soft sheath gives gentle, uniform resistance similar to dragging a marker on slightly textured paper, while the cable’s slight give prevents scraping.

Collapse the telescoping rod except for the thinnest metal segment (≈1 cm thick) and hold that segment 2–8 cm behind its tip with a precision grip.  This reproduces a long, light, cylindrical handle you can rotate between thumb and index finger and execute controlled strokes in the air, very similar to wielding an actual paint brush.

Grip the narrow neck/trigger section as you would the paint-roller handle and swing the bottle in long arcs. Because most of the mass is in the liquid-filled reservoir above your hand, you feel a mild top-heavy inertia similar to a loaded roller head. The smooth cylindrical body also lets you lightly press and ‘glide’ the base against the table to mimic the moment when the foam roller contacts a wall.
